Chip Dunning wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  > Please, please, please do not use floating point numbers to represent
>  > quantities of money. This is a classic source of error in software, and
>  > I would hate to see you present it to students as a good idea.
>  >
>  > Also, in your example, the price can be wrong by up to 1% in either
>  > direction! Is this really what you want? If the price comes back as
>  > 7.93, that's good enough?! No way.
> 
> That depends on your need. Using longs to represent everything in 
> pennies fails when you are attempting to use multiple currencies. 

<snip-explanation />

Agreed. I was merely suggesting something better, but simple, rather 
than a real solution, which would involve a Money class of some kind.

>       Now all of this could be avoided if you accept 4 decimal digits 
> for money - 1 away from your significant should cancel any rounding 
> errors, or you can get each transaction as an individual. However, if 
> you only get a lump long for the amount then it won't work.

Even if you keep 4 decimal digits, if you multiply that value by, say, 
100,000 (or worse, 92,582), you still lose accuracy.

> I have found BigDecimal is actually very accurate when you initially 
> load values into them using Strings [new BigDecimal("10.56")], so I have 
> been using them.

I haven't tried that, myself, so I should. Still, if one likes the Whole 
Value pattern, one prefers to have a Money class, that knows about 
money-related issues and can do money-related things.

Thanks for the alternatives. They're /always/ valuable.
